Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: The Teacher Practice Feedback Tool- real-time information for teachers who want to measure and improve their talk time, wait time, and question-asking skills.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project seeks to improve teaching by providing teachers with real-time, personalized feedback. Most teachers receive little regular, actionable feedback about their teaching to help them improve. Questions and discussions are the currency of great teachers, especially as teachers help students develop critical thinking, collaboration, communications and creativity skills, those skills in highest demand for careers in science, technology, engineering and math. This project is to design, develop, test and refine a mobile app that provides powerful, real-time instructional data for teachers at all grade levels and subject areas.

Through the automatic analysis of questions and discussion, teachers will have access to useful data about communication in their classrooms to help them continuously improve instruction. This project is designed to help teachers incorporate more inquiry-based instruction methods into their teaching practice. Inquiry is a research-based approach to increasing student competencies. The intended outcomes for using this application are for teachers to talk less and ask more questions, to allow sufficient wait time before calling on students, and for teachers to incorporate more and higher-level questioning into their teaching. The technology can be sold to directly teachers at schools and universities throughout the United States on a subscription basis, enabling teachers to control their own data and decide how it is used, as well as ensuring that the tool is used for improvement, rather than for evaluative purposes. The technology being developed for this project builds upon recent advancements in natural language processing and voice analysis. This project uses machine learning and algorithms to develop a user-friendly app that analyzes teacher voice data around four key data points: talk time, wait time, question level (higher-order and lower-order questions based on a proprietary taxonomy), and question frequency. The objective of this project is to design, test and refine the first version of the app, to be used on an iPhone using an external microphone. Teachers representing various grade levels, subject areas, levels of experience, and voice characteristics will pilot this technology and provide feedback to inform development. This project will employ research methodologies such as pre and post surveys, observations, interviews, and think-aloud sessions, to inform usability and feasibility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to provide teachers with feedback on their teaching. In contrast to the typical practice of teachers being observed for evaluative purposes, we sought to empower teachers with a private, non-judgmental, and personalized tool to provide feedback and the opportunity for self-reflection to inform and improve instruction.

Our Phase I research focused on the development of an initial version of the Earshot app for iOS, and on the usability and feasibility of the Earshot app. Through this project we have demonstrated that our concept is technically feasible. We have also established clear market demand for a commercial product to use voice analysis and machine learning to bring insight to human communications.

We focused this Phase I in-depth, qualitative study on K-12 teachers and teacher coaches, accounting for a range of grade levels, subject areas, levels of experience, equipment available, and school characteristics.

At the end of this Phase I pilot project, we have collected evidence demonstrating market demand among K-12 teachers and teacher coaches. The Earshot app fits within current teacher workflows and provides relevant data to inform the improvement of instruction.

We developed a scalable, cloud-based infrastructure that can grow easily and cost effectively with our user base. Our utility computing system uses microservices to enable various functionalities such as audio data collection, speaker diarization, automatic speech recognition, speaker identification, reporting, etc. This architecture allows us to evolve each of these functionalities separately, enabling us to hire optimal talent and improve each component as budgets and demand dictate. We can scale our expertise, as well as our capacity, over time.

We designed Earshot to work on a teacher’s smartphone without the need to purchase any additional hardware. The front end of our system is an iOS app that resides on the teacher’s own iPhone or iPad. Our app is designed to be used with an external microphone, such as a lapel mic, Bluetooth mic, or the earbuds that come with the phone, to enable hands-free usage while teaching.

Participants in our Phase I pilot project used the Earshot app on their smartphones to record their teaching. Participants could record as often as they wished, with a maximum record time of 50 minutes for each recorded session. Upon completion of the recording, participants were asked to rate on a scale of 1-5 how well they thought the class went and how engaged students were.

Using the Earshot app teachers could see summary data about their talk time, wait time and questions from their iPhone, as shown in Figure 1. We also provided pilot participants with more detailed reports via PDF documents sent by email.

Outside research firm Education First conducted surveys, classroom observations and interviews with pilot participants. Participants reported that the Earshot app is simple to use and the reports provide useful data for teaching. Every interviewee felt the data presented through Earshot was clear, simple to understand and sufficiently detailed.

Surveys and interviews revealed that teachers were most surprised by their wait time data. On average, participants estimated they waited 5.03 seconds before calling on students. Earshot data revealed that participants waited less than one second before calling on students. Teachers were also surprised by their talk time. In surveys conducted at the outset of our pilot project, 60% of participants estimated their talk time to be 50% or less. Data collected by Earshot during the Phase I pilot study showed that only 26% of the time teachers spoke less than 50% during class.

Teachers stated that Earshot is compelling because the teachers themselves control it. Teachers can decide what they record, when they record and who sees their data. Teachers trust the data provided by the Earshot app even when it conflicts with their perception (e.g., the teacher waited for less time than she had thought). The app makes teachers researchers, giving them ownership over their learning.

Pilot participants observed that the Earshot app lends itself to learning conversations. Teachers at any level can use the app and compare their data. The data can be used for group analysis of questioning techniques and outcomes, discussions about both talk time and silence and how to manage wait time. These conversations can lead to discussions about levels of student engagement and student empowerment in the classroom.
